measured_by: autocorrelation function (significant rate) / power spectral density slope
justification: The authors state: "We use two measures of this property… the autocorrelation function in changes between subsequent log predictions and the power spectral density of the log prediction series."

measured_by: variance of changes between successive log predictions
justification: The paper notes: "We measure this property here according to the variance in the distribution of changes between subsequent log predictions (i.e., Var[ln(p e t )−ln(p e t−1 )])."

measured_by: tail index from Generalised Pareto distribution / kurtosis of the change distribution
justification: The authors report: "first, we estimate the tail index … by fitting a Generalised Pareto distribution to the top 5% of these changes… Second, we take the kurtosis … of the distribution of changes between log predictions."

measured_by: power-law decay exponent of autocorrelation in absolute log changes
justification: They describe volatility clustering as "periods of volatility tend to be clustered… measured according to a slow decay in the autocorrelation function in absolute log change…, with markets being described by power-law decays."

measured_by: mean absolute log difference between prediction and preceding price
justification: The method section explains: "we used the mean absolute difference between each log prediction and its preceding log price for each participant … where perfectly rational responses should produce a value of zero."

measured_by: mean signed deviation of predicted log change from expected change
justification: For optimism the authors "measured according to the mean expected movement from the most recent price point," noting that positive or negative signed deviations indicate optimism or pessimism/trend damping.

measured_by: regression coefficients of predictions on the previous five price points
justification: They state: "The kernel is captured here via a regression of predictions over the recent history of prices, examining the influence of past values on subsequent forecasts… using the five preceding price values as predictors."
